title: Sarah Nouwen
text:
Sarah M.H. Nouwen is an academic in the areas of international law of <a href="peacemaking">peacemaking</a> and <a href="justice">justice</a>. She is a Professor of <a href="International%20law">International Law</a> at the <a href="European%20University%20Institute">European University Institute</a>, <a href="Florence">Florence</a>, Italy, in the Department of Law, on leave as a Reader in International Law and Fellow of the <a href="Lauterpacht%20Centre%20for%20International%20Law">Lauterpacht Centre for International Law</a> at the <a href="University%20of%20Cambridge">University of Cambridge</a> and Fellow of <a href="Pembroke%20College%2C%20Cambridge">Pembroke College, Cambridge</a>. She is also an <a href="Editor-in-chief">Editor in Chief</a> of the <a href="European%20Journal%20of%20International%20Law">European Journal of International Law</a>.
Career.
Nouwen studied law (<a href="Law%20of%20the%20Netherlands">Dutch law</a> and <a href="international%20law">international law</a>) at <a href="Utrecht%20University">Utrecht University</a> receiving an LLB and LLM, part of which she completed at the <a href="University%20of%20the%20Western%20Cape">University of Western Cape</a> and the <a href="University%20of%20Cape%20Town">University of Cape Town</a>, <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a>. Subsequently, she obtained an MPhil in International Relations and a PhD in Law from the University of Cambridge.  
Prior to assuming her academic roles, she worked in international diplomacy for the <a href="Ministry%20of%20Foreign%20Affairs%20%28Netherlands%29">Netherlands Ministry of Foreign Affairs</a> in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York</a>, <a href="The%20Hague">The Hague</a>, the Netherlands Embassy in <a href="Khartoum">Khartoum</a> (2005-2006) and the UK Department for International Development in <a href="Darfur">Darfur</a> advising on <a href="transitional%20justice">transitional justice</a>, <a href="peace%20negotiations">peace negotiations</a>, and the <a href="rule%20of%20law">rule of law</a>. From 2010-2011 she was Senior Legal Advisor to the African Union High-Level Panel on Sudan assisting with negotiations on peace for Darfur, and on <a href="Succession%20of%20states">state succession</a> between the <a href="Government%20of%20Sudan">Government of Sudan</a> and the <a href="Southern%20Sudan%20autonomous%20region%20%282005%E2%80%932011%29">Government of Southern Sudan</a>. In 2014, Nouwen received the <a href="Philip%20Leverhulme%20Prize">Philip Leverhulme Prize</a> which recognizes researchers with a promising career who are receiving international recognition for their work.
She was a <a href="Fellow">Senior Fellow</a> of the <a href="World%20Peace%20Foundation">World Peace Foundation</a> at the <a href="Fletcher%20School%20of%20Law%20and%20Diplomacy">Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy</a>, <a href="Tufts%20University">Tufts University</a>, <a href="Boston">Boston</a>. She has also been a <a href="visiting%20scholar">visiting scholar</a> at the <a href="Vrije%20Universiteit%20Amsterdam">Free University of Amsterdam</a> and a <a href="Research%20associate">Research Associate</a> of the Refugee Law Project, <a href="Makerere%20University">Makerere University</a>, <a href="Kampala">Kampala</a>.
Her research interests include a broad range of domains in international law, <a href="international%20human%20rights%20law">international human rights law</a>, transitional justice, peace negotiations/peacekeeping/peacebuilding/peacemaking, <a href="Third%20World%20Approaches%20to%20International%20Law">third world approaches to international law</a>, anthropological approaches to international law and the <a href="history%20of%20international%20law">history of international law</a> among others.
Nouwen has given guest lectures across the world including at universities in <a href="Australia">Australia</a>, <a href="Europe">Europe</a>, <a href="North%20America">North America</a>, and <a href="Africa">Africa</a>.
